official-title.#text:
To award a Congressional Gold Medal to Rabbi Arthur
		  Schneier in recognition of his pioneering role in promoting religious freedom
		  and human rights throughout the world, for close to half a
		  century.

sponsor.#text:
Mrs. Carolyn B. Maloney of New
			 York

cosponsor.#tail:
) introduced the following
			 bill; which was referred to the

short-title.#text:
Rabbi Arthur Schneier Congressional
			 Gold Medal Act

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the
The

Rabbi Arthur Schneier, Spiritual Leader of
			 Park East Synagogue and Founder and President, Appeal of Conscience Foundation,
			 has played a pioneering role in promoting religious freedom and human rights
			 throughout the world, for close to half a century.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
of the United States awarded
			 him the Presidential Citizens Medal for

quote.#text:
his service as an international
			 envoy for four administrations

devoting a lifetime to overcoming forces of hatred and
			 intolerance

text.#text: The

quote.#text:
… his ecumenical work in favor of mutual understanding,
			 tolerance and peace …

text.#text:
He received the
			 United States Department of State Special Recognition Award from Secretary
			 Colin Powell for

In China in 2004,
			 he headed an interfaith Appeal of Conscience Foundation delegation which met
			 with government officials on behalf of religious freedom and strengthened
			 exchanges between religious communities in China and the United States.

He has regularly
			 led delegations of religious leaders to China since the early 1980s.

In the Former
			 Soviet Union, Rabbi Schneier was, in 2004, the keynote speaker at the
			 Interreligious Conference on Peace hosted by Patriarch Aleksey II.

In Armenia in
			 2002, he held meetings with the Catholicos of all Armenians and government
			 leaders to help ease tensions between Armenia and Turkey.

He convened the
			 Religious Summit on the Former Yugoslavia in Switzerland and the Conflict
			 Resolution Conference in Vienna, mobilizing Catholic, Muslim, and Orthodox
			 Christian religious leaders to halt the bloodshed in former Yugoslavia (1992,
			 1995).

In the Balkans,
			 Caucasus, and Central Asia, he initiated the Peace and Tolerance Conference in
			 Istanbul, Turkey, in cooperation with the Turkish Government and the Ecumenical
			 Patriarch Bartholomew I (1994).

In
			 Bosnia-Herzegovina, he met with top government and religious leaders in
			 Sarajevo to promote healing and conciliation between the Serbian Orthodox,
			 Muslim, Catholic, and Jewish communities (1997).

Rabbi Schneier
			 initiated the interfaith appeal to the United Nations for the worldwide
			 protection of holy sites, which was adopted by the United Nations General
			 Assembly in May 2001 as the resolution for the

In 1980, he
			 initiated the Annual Seminar on Religious Life to educate Foreign Service
			 officers in the religious traditions of the countries of their
			 assignment.

quote.#text:
20 years of excellent
			 cooperation in furthering the objective of religious freedom

text.#text:
The Foreign
			 Service Institute honored him in 2001 for

quote.#text:
for
			 his 30 years of partnership in helping Foreign Affairs professionals to better
			 understand the right to religious freedom in the countries in which they
			 serve

text.#text:
He was awarded the Department of State
			 Special Recognition Award from Secretary of State Hillary Clinton

He has been very
			 active in humanitarian missions, such as mobilizing the American religious
			 community in support for the victims of the Armenian and Turkish earthquakes
			 and Romanian floods.

A United States
			 Alternate Representative to the United Nations General Assembly and Chairman of
			 the United States Commission for the Preservation of America’s Heritage Abroad,
			 he was one of 3 American religious leaders appointed by the President of the
			 United States to start the first dialogue on religious freedom with President
			 Jiang Zemin and other top Chinese leaders (1998).

He was a United
			 States delegate to the Stockholm International Forum for the Prevention of
			 Genocide (2004).

Born in Vienna,
			 Austria, in 1930, Rabbi Schneier lived under Nazi occupation in Budapest during
			 World War II and arrived in the United States in 1947.

He holds the
			 Ordination and Doctor of Divinity Degree from Yeshiva University.

In 2004, Yeshiva
			 University honored him by establishing the Rabbi Arthur Schneier Center for
			 International Affairs.

He hosted Pope Benedict XVI at Park East
			 Synagogue, the first visit of a Pope to a synagogue in the United States
			 (2008), and the Ecumenical Patriarch Bartholomew (2009).

He was invited by
			 King Abdullah of Saudi Arabia as a keynote to the Interfaith Conference
			 (Madrid) (2008).

term.#tail:
(2005) and he was appointed Ambassador of the UN Alliance
			 of Civilizations (2009).

text.#text:
He was appointed
			 by the UN Secretary General to the High Level Group

He was honored
			 with the Knight Commander of the Order of Civil Merit by the Kingdom of Spain,
			 Officer of the Order of the Légion d’honneur of France, Officer’s Cross of the
			 Order of Merit of Germany, Grand Decoration of Honor in Gold with Star for
			 Service to the Republic of Austria, Order of the Republic of Hungary, Officer’s
			 Cross of the Order of Merit of the Republic of Poland, the Order of the Star of
			 Italian Solidarity, Grand Decoration of Honor in Gold for Special Services to
			 the Province of Vienna.

quote.#text:
his leadership in inter-religious
			 cooperation and the strengthening of ties between American religious
			 communities and the Russian Orthodox Church

text.#text:
He received the
			 Order of St. Daniel of Moscow, for

quote.#text:
solidarity with Armenians in the cause
			 of human rights

text.#text:
He was selected
			 Friend of the Armenians for his

quote.#text:
his
			 contributions to the improvement of tolerance and peace among all religions
			 throughout the world

text.#text:
He received the
			 Order of St. Andrew the Apostle Athenagoras Human Rights Award for

He received the
			 Guru Nanac Interfaith Prize, Hofstra University for

He was the
			 recipient of eleven honorary doctorates from United States and foreign
			 universities.
